list.item: Hartwell, a young gentleman, lover of mistress Frances.
Three servants, disguised sometimes as lords, one of them once disguised as a pursuivant.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.p: Nay, let's not part so heavily.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: For mine own part
It does not trouble me so much, that you
Have broke up house; for hospitality
Went out of fashion with crop-doublets
And codpieces: but I that have worn out
So many liveries under the worshipful
Old gentleman your father.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: My father had an office, which brought in
A fair revenue; I inherit but
His little land, whose annual profits won't
Encourage me to live at the same height:
Ye may meet better fortunes, there's enough
Preferment in the world; my love and best
Assistance promise to yourselves.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I do not
Stand upon wages, sir, I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: As other mortals do; yet I'll not play
The thief, that is a course by which a man
May soon ascend the ladder of preferment:
But I never loved these climbing trees. I cannot
Cheat, though I have heard there is an art,
A devilish deal of knowledge in the dice;
And if men wonot part with money, some
Will fetch it out o'th' bones: but the best casting
Is in a tavern, when the wine and reckoning
Come up together; some do spin a living by't:
And there are many secret ways for serving-men
To live, it is not wages does maintain
All of our tribe, sir; and especially
Those that have mistresses.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I pray let me be one of your buttons still then,
I am not half worn out; you know what mould
I'm made off, I did ever honest service;
And though my fellow vermin can forsake
Your falling house, I do not fear the rafters;
By this hand, sir, I'll wait upon you, though
Like great men's servants, I do live on nothing
But looks, and the air of commendations.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Well, since you are so resolute, attend me,
The rest I here discharge, there's somewhat more,
Not worth the name of bounty, I wish all
A happier entertainment.

sp.speaker: 2 serv.
sp.l: And there be
No remedy, heaven bless you, sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wet my lips with these
My fellows, sorrow has made but a dry proverb,
I must toth' tavern, and condole a quart.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Meet me at mistress Bellamy's then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You speak not
To me, sir, I am a servant still indeed;
With them the case is altered, they are masters,
For they want services.
It is not now as when Andrea lived,

sp.p: This place was made for pleasure, not for death.
There was a time when mortals whetted knives.
In time of yore, when men killed brutish beasts.
O cruel butcher, whosoever thou wert.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Do not you know what all this signifies?

sp.l: He has committed burglary, broke up the cellar,
And thrown the kitchen out at the hall window.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: His house, sir, has a superscription,
And is directed to his loving friend
Will pay the rent, you'll hardly know me now,
I have no fellow.

sp.p: He has some cause, we are discharged.

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: For certain, my master only
Belongs to me, if you would speak with him,
He's gone to mistress Bellamy's, sir;
In the mean time, please you to understand,
I close follow my master, and shall feed still,
Although my fellows here are become blanks,
And do want filling.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Lads, I have known you long:
Although you be at loss, in confidence
Of all your future honesties, I'll employ ye
In a device, which if it hit, may
Reward your pains.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Your master only, sir, belongs to you,
Follow him still, and if there be occasion,
I shall inquire for you; you will be faithful.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I have a project,
Follow me for instructions; farewell close,
Commend me to your master.

sp.p: Buoy close, buoy honest close, we are blanks, blanks.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Roll up yourselves in paper-liveries, and
Be drawn at the next lottery; I won't
Forsake my certainty for all your projects,
If it should fail I shall find some of you
Sneaking in Paul's behind a pillar, with
A zealous prayer, some gentleman would read
The beadroll of your commendation,
And pity a very serviceable fellow,
That would fain wait on him, but wants a cloak:
Go, prosper with your project. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Widow, be ruled by me, I know the world,
And I have studied it these fifty years:
There's no man to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Without good.
Security, you mean.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: No young man, widow,
That talks, and says he loves you, writes you verses,
And swears he shall go hang himself, unless
You pity him; take me an old man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, take you an old man.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Seasoned with care and thrift, not led away
By vicious conversation, nor corrupted
With pride and surfeit, one that knows the use
Of money; do ye mark the use?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, sir:
Use upon use, you mean.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And dares not spend it prodigally, knowing
the principal end it was ordained to, was
To relieve our necessity, and lay up
What is above.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You may,
If you be so disposed, but 'tis as commendable
To give it in your will, to build an hospital,
And so our charity comes altogether:
I would not have your state be eaten up
By caterpillars, but preserved and made
Greater, by marrying some discreet old man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And such an one you show yourself.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You happily
Interpret me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I would not tell you, sir,
Till our next meeting, how much you have won,
By your good counsel, on me.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: She inclines.
'Tis your good nature, I am plain, and have
No tricks, I'll tell you all my fault, I am
Addicted very much to gather wealth;
I have no children to devour my state,
Nor kindred, only a niece left to my trust,
One that is never like to marry.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: She never thrived since she came to me.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Melancholy
Will kill her, and yet I pursue all ways
That promise her delight: I spare no cost
Of physic, what her doctor says, is done.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A gentleman that bears my daughter much
Affection.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: O, he's a beggar, or must be very shortly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Have you his lands in mortgage?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Not yet, not yet; but he'll want money, widow.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Hang breeding, 'tis unlucky,
They never keep their state that have too much on't,
Counsel your daughter, mistress Bellamy,
To throw him off betime.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: When we are married, I'll provide a match for her.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Is he suitor to your mother, lady?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He would be such a thing: were not I blessed
In such a jolly father in law?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: He looks like some cast moneybag, that had given up
The stuffing, and for want of use grown mouldy:
He dares not keep much fire in's kitchen, lest
Warming his hands, which rather look like gloves,
So tanned and thin, he let 'em scorch, and gather
Into a heap. I do not think he ever
Put off his clothes, he would run mad to see
His own anatomy, that such a wretch
Should have so vast a wealth.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I would not be his
Niece for all his fortune.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I presume
Your mother is more noble, than to encourage him
In his pretence, and her estate would mix
But ill with his ill-gotten wealth, extorted
From widows and from or plans, nor will all
His plenty keep his soul one day from famine:
'Tis time ill spent to mention him, let's talk
Of something else.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Of love again,
Whose flame we equally divide.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Your table
Is a devourer, and they shut up doors
First, that keep open house and entertainments:
This lord is feasted, and that young lady's
Sweet tooth must have a banquet; tother old
Madam with never a tooth must have some marchpane
Coral to rub her gums withal; these are
Ridiculous expenses.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: This room has too rich furniture, and worse
Hangings would serve the turn; if I may be
Worthy to counsel, costly pictures are
Superfluous, though of this, or tother masters
Doing: hang Michael Angelo and his oils.
If they be given, you're the more excused
To let 'em show; but have a care you let not
Appear, either in arras, or in picture,
The story of the prodigal, 'twill fright ▪
Young gentlemen that come to visit you
From spending o'their portions, whose riot
May enrich you with their forfeited estates;
I have a thousand precepts more.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But do not
Think all this while of heaven.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: 'Tis in my chest,
And multiplied in every bag.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: A fable to fright fools, or children; but
I cannot stay, my scrivener doth expect me,
I'll visit you another time, sweet widow,
And give you more instructions.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Spare your travel ▪
I sha'not practise these in haste, and must
declare these precepts make not for your welcome:
My patience was a virtue all this while,
If you but think you have a soul; repent;
Your rules I am not covetous to follow,
Good master Hornet.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Live and be undone then:
You'll tell me another tale hereafter widow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Letters from master Startup, the country gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A suitor of my nurse's commendations.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now heaven deliver me, what have I seen?
This monster once was shown i'th' fair, or such
Another furred baboon for all the world,
Dost know him? Why do I ask such a question?
He's such a thing the devil would not own's
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Hornet? Nay then, my wonder's over, and the
Devil be but such another, they
May be sworn brothers; yes, and divide hell
Betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Who is that you talk on, sir?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The beast, that heaven be thanked, has left you,
Hornet ▪ but I ha' news for you.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: I'll hear it in the garden. Exit Hart. Close.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Do you love
That master Hartwell? do not blush, but answer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I hope you move not this, as if you doubted;
I took him first, upon your character,
Into my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But things alter:
What then I thought, I delivered ye;
Nor since hath he deserved a less esteem
In his own person, but the circumstance
is not the same, his fortune I have examined,
Which rises not to such a value, I
Did apprehend; and it becomes my care,
Being at one gift to depart with thee
And my estate, to look for one whose purse
May carry a proportion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Make me not
Imagine you would wed me to a heap
Of shining dust, a golden bondage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nor
To penury; his birth, and education
Are not unworthy, he's a handsome man too;
But be not governed by your eye too much:
Children and age pursue, and many storms
Hover about our frail conditions:
All these must be provided for, they are not
Kisses will arm you against winter, therefore
Confident of your obedience, I propound
Another to your best thoughts,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A country gentleman of spreading fortunes,
Young too, and not uncomely; for his breeding,
It was not spun the finest, but his wealth,
Able to guild deformity, and make
Even want of wit a virtue, when your life
Renders itself more sweet by your command;
His name is master Startup, whom I expect
Our guest tomorrow, that's his letter, read it.
This may seem strange at the first coming towards you;
But when discretion comes to examine what
A fruitful consequence attends it, you
Will thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But with your pardon, mother,
Although I could dispense with my own thoughts,
And frame them to obedience, will this change
Be for my honour, or my fame? when such
a noble gentleman shall boast he had,
With your consent, my love? or pray admit
That which we gain by riches of the second,
Seem to authorise, and may justify
The act with some; how can it cure the wound,
Which the poor heart, which loves, shall find too soon,
When 'tis neglected, and so cruelly,
Where it did hope for cherishing? O think
How you did love my father first, and be
More gentle to your daughter, your estate
Is above needy providence, or grafting
Into a new stock; it doth grow already
Fair from his own root, and doth want no piecing:
Nor are the means of Hartwell so contemptible.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: No more: you've considered well, you'll shape
Another answer; i'th' mean time dispose
Your countenance to entertain this new
And able lover: leave the satisfaction
Of Hartwell to my care:
He's here, to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I know not what's the trick on't, nor themselves yet;
But he has a project to employ 'em all ▪

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I wish it well; but do you work yourself
Into the opinion of her nurse, she is
The major domo, and has all the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll work her sir like wax,
To print what form you please upon her, 'tis
A loving crone already to me, I
Will speak her fair, and in my drink may marry her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: There is a matter, sir, which I must open,
And you perhaps will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You do love my daughter,
at least I think so.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: If you knew my heart,
You might be confident, in her I sum
All my desires on earth.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: When you have heard me out, you'll find
Your consent easy to call back a promise
Made to your disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I acknowledge;
This makes me wonder, pray interpret lady,
And speak the dialect I understand:
I love your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But must never glory
In the reward which you expect should be,
Her marriage.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: In the number of my actions
There is not one that's guilty of so much
Offence to you, that I should be so soon
Lost to your favour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Have no thought so poor
You can deserve less, my opinion
Is richer laden with your merit.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Now I fear again, this violent turn of praise
Makes me suspect my state; if I be fallen,
Teach me to know my trespass.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I never looked
With such clear eyes into your worth, and 'twere
A sin to general goodness, to delay
The free resign of that your worth may challenge.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: If this be meant, pray pardon my mistake
Of something went before, love made me fear;
You said I never should enjoy your daughter
In marriage, which yourself so late inclined to.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And must again repeat, you cannot call
Her bride.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Can you forbid this happiness,
And love me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes, so dear, Hartwell, I
Present myself to thy affection.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Does the name
Of widow sound displeasing, I have learned
Already to obey; my years are not
So many, with the thought, to freeze your blood,
I wear no print of time deep in my brow:
Have my hairs the innocence of age,
To speak me twice a child? Gentlemen active,
And of great birth, have courted my affection,
And if they flatter not, commend my person.
Add unto this my wealth, no narrow fortune,
And without competition, my daughter,
Depending on my love, whose portion must
Flow from my bounty, or be nothing; make
A sober apprehension of this tender,
And think I was not able to suppress
My silent flame, increased still by your virtues:
This minute give all hopes up for my daughter,
I can admit no rival; 'tis within
Your election to be happy, sir:
My love accepted comes with fair attendance,
Denied, you hasten your own exile, think on't,
I will expect your answer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I am destroyed:
Was it her mother that spoke all this while?
As pilgrims, by mistake of some small path,
Having told many weary steps, at night,
When their hopes flatter 'em, they are not far
From some kind entertainment, find themselves
Lost in a wilderness; so am I miserable:
Thus love delights to wound, and see us bleed,
He were a gentle god to kill indeed. Exit.

div.head: Act. ii.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A word of thy mouth does it, I am weary
Of these indentures, like a fool, I was
In hope he should have married mistress Frances.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: A beggar, she his wife; no, master Startup,
Whom I preferred, must carry her, he's a man
Of lands and money; I must tell you by
The way, he is little better than a fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: The fitter for her husband, and my master.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You're in the right, he's innocent to your hands,
You may soon come to manage his estate.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Which if I do, thou shalt have all.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why all that I can beg, borrow, or steal
From him; what should he do with so much riches?
I'll prompt my mistress, after the first year,
To put him to his pension; he should pay
For's very diet, and after a month or two,
For every time he comes all oft.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay, I would wish her to begin betimes,
If she do mean to rule the roost, I can
Give her some documents; and be you sure
To stick close to your mistress, there is something
To be got that way.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My most exquisite Varges,
How I do love thy documents; but he's here,
I'll not be seen with thee, farewell, we'll talk
The rest at night over a sack-posset. Exit Close.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I will use this advantage to o'erhear 'em.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You tell me strange things; is it possible
The widow herself loves you?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Would I had
But reason to suspect.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Possible!
Turned colt again? This love will kill us all:
And can she make no choice, but where her daughter
Has the same longing? not her dancing days
Done yet? why there's no remedy, you must love her.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: And violate my faith made to her daughter.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Thou wot not be so much an infidel,
To think I mean thou shouldst forsake the wench;
Tell me the mother a fine tale of love,
Print kisses on her paper-lip, and hug
Her reverend body; any thing but lie with her:
Write sonnets on the ivory tooth afore,
Swear she does cough distinctly, get a rhyme
To bless her when she sneezes, and cry up
The method of her nose, which sweats and falls
So perpendicular upon her face:
Admire the wart upon her chin, and motion
Of her blue eyes, that look three ways at once:
Praise her above thy reason, or her daughter;
And than she will believe thou mayst be mad for her.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Is this the way to do me good? she comes
Too fast on me already.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Let her fly to thee,
Thou mayst clip her wings the sooner, this secures thee;
Should you hold off, and play the modest creature;
Nay, but deny as maids do when they love it,
And bending of your hams, cry, no forsooth;
Profess with coxcomb-like civility,
You are not worthy of her carnal favours:
She may believe it, and in very spite
Marry her daughter to a citizen:
Or should you be so mad, to think to win her
to your first choice, with howling out your passion
For mistress Frances, plaining how don Cupid
Hath scarified your heart, you may go hang yourself:
Go to the barbers, let him firk your hair up,
Or get a periwig; wash your sullen face,
And starch your infant upper lip, to look
Like one that would run desperate on a widow.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: This is the way:
At leisure you may tell your maiden mistress,
Like Jove you have put another shape on,
To cheat the beldame Juno.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I apprehend: thou'st given me good counsel,
I'll watch the first occasion, to assure
I have preferred her in my heart already.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I'll conjure up a cross plot, and that quickly,
Shall mar your mirth, and pay your fine dissembling
As it deserves, my confident love-gamester. Exit nurse.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I'll take my leave then, you've no other service
To use my stay? I have a project, Hartwell,
That must not be neglected.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Thou art engaged to wait
Upon thine own affairs, or I should trouble thee
To be an actor in't; thou knowest old Hornet?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: He is a suitor to the widow,
And after the rate we cast the plot, my rival.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I'll rival him; he smothers a poor gentlewoman
At home with seacoal, and allows her no
More light than serves to read in painted cloth
The exposition of the harlot's story:
Hartwell, I love her, and before her father
Died we interchanged our hearts; 'tis here,
To free her from that slavery she lives in
Under the iron-hearted jailor, else
I shall repent my aim, he broods upon
Her portion still; but I have a trick may spoil
His hatching of young bags, thou shalt know all
Hereafter; to the widow, Hartwell, I am
For state affairs, be faithful and pray for me;
We must be bold, farewell, if something hit
We'll laugh in spite of Dives and the devil. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Startup, mistress Bellamy, mistress Frances, close, nurse, Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: This is the thing, sir, that must carry away
The garland, they have given him a cup
Or two of sack, and has the prettiest humour,
He does so whistle out his compliment:
He wears his feather like the captain of
A country team, and would become a horse-collar
Rarely; I do not think, but were he put to 't,
With little switching, he would draw the cart well.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet lady, I'm your humble servant, 'tis
Well known what I am, where I live, my father
Died since I was of age; and left me, thank him,
A younger brother's portion:

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I know, sweet lady, what you'd say, my father
Had no more children, but I must speak modestly
Of my estate, I have land I know enough
For two or three wives; I have a horse in town,
Your daughter, if we please, shall ride behind me,
Sweet lady, did you ever see the country?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Why any country living,
Sweet lady, I am your humble servant, if
You affect hawking, hunting, or drinking,
There be good fellows will bear you company; but you have
Better sack, sweet lady, is there good tobacco in London?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet sir, I am your humble servant, you
Seem to be a gentleman, will you fetch me a pipe?
There's half a piece, and I be not troublesome:
Perhaps, sweet lady, 'twill offend you, then
Let it alone.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A very precious widgeon: gramercy sack.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Ta la la la lero, etc.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: He has a strong back, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet lady, is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: That may be too: what gentleman is that?
Sweet sir, I am your humble servant likewise.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: You are too humble, sir, to stoop so low,
It would become my duty.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet sir, 'tis all one,
A leg or an arm is not cast away
Among friends, I am a country gentleman
All the world knows, sweet sir, I ha' no business
In town.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I thought you came to see my daughter.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: That may be too, sweet lady, pray uncase me,
I honour your fair daughter; for I know,
As well as another, what belongs to a gentlewoman:
She's not the first, sweet lady, I've loved
I'th' way of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet sir, no ▪ all men are not alike.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet sir, I do confess it:
But wit is never goodwill it be bought.
They say there are good wits in town,
I ha' brought money a purpose 〈◊〉 me for it;
If any will sell me a pennyworth, I'll
give him a hundred pieces, 'cause I would carry
A little down into the country.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Is there
A dearth, sir, in your country?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet sir, no;
There's plenty.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Of wild oats; I heard you had much
To sow still.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: My servants have, sweet sir; but 'tis all one;
This lady shall be lord of the soil: I won't
Give any man six pence for a bushel of money;
I am a gentleman, my father was
A yeoman; but sweet lady, howsoever
I'm yours, and every limb is at your service;
My hands shall walk, my feet shall run.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Not run? my grandfather was a nobleman footman, and indeed he run his country; my father did out run the constable.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: And he, sweet lady, being his father's issue, must run naturally.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He'll run himself out of all.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Not run, sweet lady ▪
If you have occasion to use me, I won't stand upon my feet.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Nay, I won't stand upon my head, sweet lady, to do you courtesy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That were the clean contrary way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Please you, a sorry dinner stays for you.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet lady, I am your servant: will this gentleman dine with us?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Do ye know what you ha' done? he's you rival, invite him?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet sir, I invite nobody , if you love anybody here?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet sir, I sha'not take it kindly, I do not use to quarrel.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: But when you're beaten: lay him o'er the face, he sha'not wrong you.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet sir, 'tis dinner time: fair lady:Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I had a great mind to have him beaten;
But he's not valiant, but at meals; would I
Were hired to beat him handsomely after dinner,
And make him thank me for't; I'll have a plot
Upon your precious body, my sweet sir. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Hornet, Playfaires cousin like a doctor.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You tell me wonders, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I tell you truth:
Alas, you know I have no ends of profit,
I practise not for wealth.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You're virtuous;
For that you were commended, sir, to me:
You have a conscience, and won't take
Fees for a compliment, nor make poor your friends,
To enrich apothecaries.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I have cured her melancholy; but she's a tother side
Now extreme merry, dance and sing, all air.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, methinks, nothing but extremities:
Good master doctors could you not ha' pared
Her tother leaden humour.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sir, I could not
Kill the malignity of her melancholy
Another way; extremities must be cured
With extreme applications: my next work
Shall be to abate this levity of her brain,
And qualify her spleen, sir, by degrees;
So state her body in that modest temper
She was possessed of.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I complained before
Of quietness, now she's all noise and madness,
By your description.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You must have patience
A month or so, she is not mad, but merry,
Some few vagaries; you must understand
I have opened, sir, her fancy, wherein lay
All her imaginations confused,
And on a heap, smothered for want of vent;
And now the spirits that were imprisoned
Rush out, which causes all her faculties,
Before oppressed, to exercise so strangely,
As the agitation of her tongue will manifest ▪
She's here.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Uncle, how does your body? you appear
As lean as Lent, I've a great mind to dance
About a maypole, shall we?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: This doctor has for tick led me,
I cannot choose but laugh, ha, ha.
Uncle, if you'll procure a dispensation
To marry me yourself, deduct the charge
Out of my portion, I could love an old man
Rarely, an old man with a bed full of bones etc.Sings.
Uncle, when did you put on a clean shirt?
D'ye hear, I dreamt o'th' devil last night,
They say 'tis good luck; do you know him, uncle ▪

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: He's a fine old gentleman,
And something like you, no such bugbear as
The world imagines, you an he'll keep house
Together one day; but you'll burn sea - 〈◊〉
To save charges, and stink the poor souls so.
Uncle, you are not merry, I pray laugh
A little: imagine y'had undone a widow,
Or turned an orphan begging; ha, ha, etc.
Faith how many churches do you mean to build
Before you die? six bells in every steeple,
And let 'em all go to the city tune,
Turn again Whittington; who, they say,
Grew rich, and let his land out for nine lives,
'Cause all came in by a cat: but let me counsel you
To die at all adventures, great men do't in policy.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Why does she talk of dying? she's stark mad.
Could you not put into the next receipt
Something to make her sleep well? Opium
In a good quantity, they say, will do't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I'll so proportion it, she shall never wake:
I did it for a merchant's wife last week,
Which loved a knight: a great man, not long since
Was weary of his countess, and I cured him
So artificially of his disease.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: But collects nothing; all her senses are scattered.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Stay, you shall give towards the building of a church
Nothing, see the money first laid out,
That's given already; it were sin and pity
To abuse the dead: but 'tis no matter, uncle,
You'll be as famous for pulling down the parish,
The church will fall of itself, with ding dung bell. Sings.
Why did they put the poor fellow in prison?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Why the corn-cutter:
Poor gentleman, he meant no hurt to the city,
His feet were very weary, and that made him
In every street cry out; ha ye any corns
In your head or toes? that head spoiled all.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Prithee, what's he? he comes to borrow money
On his wife's wedding-ring, or his child's whistle:
You may see by his nose he has no laud, he looks
As a hawk; what do you dream on?
What lady's timpany is your next cure?
Or whose stale body must be rectified
Next with a glister?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.p: There is no disputing, I must attend you.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I am sent for by a pursuivant to his highness;
Alas, I am undone, I never saw him,
How should he know me, a poor wretch?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Is't not some complaint, think you?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: That's my fear, there be
Too many knaves i'th' world, and a man cannot
Grow rich; but one state-surgeon or other
Must practise on his purse; before this judge
A vein is opened in the other court,
So many ounces he must bleed again:
Let me see, all the treason I committed
Is that I shifted houses; for I took
Delight to cozen him of his subsidies;
I always live obscurely, to avoid
Taxations, I never pay the church
Her superstitious tithes, nor come to trouble
Sermons, for fear of homilies before,
That beg for burning.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Why how now, uncle, is your scrivener broke,
You talk such lamentation?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I am sent for the King, niece, and shall be made a beggar
As I was born; I see my chattel ceased,
This chest is ransacked, and that bag deflowered,
My door sealed up, and with this hungry messenger,
I am already marching to the fleet.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Nay, and you be at that ward, I must leave you,
fare well, pray do not lift my uncle too hard;
And so I leave you both to the mercy of the bear-garden.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Wo' not some money qualify your haste?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.p: Deal in your own affairs; will you go sit?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I'll take my leave;
Have comfort, sir, this cloud may soon blow over. Exit.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Yes, when I am blown up;
I read imprisonment in his very looks,
And all my gold confiscate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I heard her say she would walk up to her chamber,
The trick was but to teach him whither he
Should follow; who as nimbly apprehended,
To acquaint her with his new affections:
I do this for your good, that mistress Frances,
Whom I'll send to you presently, may be
Convinced in Hartwell's falsehood, and transplant
Her love on you.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: This will be excellent;
So we shall strangle him in his own noose,
And he ne'er know who hurt him.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I'll lose no time, you know my instructions.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: I had almost forgotten, there is a cast of angels more.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: If thou dost fear they'll drown, nurse, I can give thee
Lighter, I have some want weight.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: If you have an evil angel about you,
Your business will thrive better when 'tis departed.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Now all the good ones wait upon your worship. Exit.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: These things that go to and again, must have
Their fees, they'll never speak in cause else.
Save you sweet lady. Enter Frances ▪

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Yes, I am kind if you knew all, but you are
Deceived in somebody ; love, and love your heart out,
The party does not care a button for you.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: No, I am a fool, a country clod, sweet lady,
Not worth one of your shoe-ties, no not I;
I do not know who makes an ass of you.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: A gull, a coxcomb, I am ashamed you have
So little wit; tell me, and tell me truly,
Who loves this face of yours besides myself.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Although it were immodest to commend it,
I must thus far, in gratitude to nature,
Acknowledge it no monster, I have seen
One more deformed.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Sweet lady I know that;
A worse face would become the country, nay,
There are but fifteen women in the parish
I live in, of which, twelve are counted witches,
And wear beards: but it troubles me, sweet lady,
You should be such an owl.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Not to see who abuses you; o I could
Now find in my heart to baste you, baste you soundly:
You think Mr. Hartwell loves you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I
Believe he hates me not.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: You lie most basely, he affects your mother.

sp.speaker: Start
sp.l: I would it were
The fashion for women to wear swords.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: I'd breathe you into a little understanding,
I say again, and she is the son of darkness
Denies it; Mr. Hartwell loves your mother.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: O I could kick your ignorance:
He does love her in the way of matrimony,
And makes a property of you; I'll justify it.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: D'ye know that couple? Enter Hartwell and Bellamy.
Step behind the hangings, and you may
Both hear and see: I say no more, sweet lady,
I am a rustic puppy, and know nothing.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I have considered perfectly, and if
You will vouchsafe me hearing, dare pour forth
My heart, which, full of love, tenders itself
To your acceptance; I acknowledge lady,
My passions are but young, for could I hope
You should with so much favour look upon me?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: But suspect were an injustice to my faith, which looks
Upon your virtue with as much religion
As love is able to receive; your age
Hath struck a reverence into my eye;
And what you want of youth and spring upon you,
Your wisdom richly satisfies: those characters
Which time hath writ upon your careful forehead,
Are but his virtue and your ornament,
When it shall come to pass by your example,
That youth shall be esteemed an infancy,
And women never ripe for love or marriage
Without your age upon 'em; 'tis a fault,
That men not guided by the tract of reason,
But heat and wantonness of blood, run giddy
To seal such weighty covenants, better 'twere
The world should end in our virginities,
Than spin itself more length by inconsiderate
And hasty marriages.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Have you already
Retrieved the affection that pursued my daughter?
Shall I believe no seed of love remains,
Which may grow up and ripen, with repentance
For this exchange; I do allow you, sir,
The consideration of my fortune, which
Might of itself, incline you to accept me.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: That is but an attendant, as you use it,
I must confess a welcome one; although
The mind is the first beauty, which true love
Aspires to, when 'tis waited on with person
And estate, it comes with greater privilege
To win upon's; I do not wish you, lady,
Rashly believe what I profess, but measure
My service by the trial; I'll expect
And write your smiles a competent reward,
Till time and your command, demonstrate me;
Although not equal to your full deservings,
Yet one that has ambition to bethought
Not too unworthy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And I guess ere long,
Such an occasion will present itself.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Till then, have Hartwell in your loving memory,
Who wishes no more happiness of life,
Than to be called yours. Exit.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Will you believe me another time, sweet lady?
If I loved you not, what would become on you?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is not he, some devil does but cozen us,
And mock our sense with these fantastic bodies,
Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Nay 'tis the man; I hope you'll be converted,
And think a country gentleman worth favour,
That brought you to this knowledge; I deserve —

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My curses for this black discovery,
Whenas before 'twas not impossible,
in time I might be brought to pity thee;
Henceforth I'll look upon thee as my sins,
And beg as much forgiveness that I knew thee.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: This is very fine i'faith, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My mother, o my fate, see me no more,
And I'll forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Thank you, most sweet lady,
Is my discovery come to this? I'd better
Ha' been tongue-tied; curse me, and call me her sins,
And see her no more? why this is worse and worse;
I must suck better counsel from the nurse. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. iii.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Fie, fie, I am ashamed of you, a gentleman
Of your high promising, and be put off
So slightly?

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: Why nurse, what would you ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Do? I would have you do something; a man
Of your ability, and cannot turn
And wind a woman?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: You would not ha' wished me
To ha' put her to't behind the hangings?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: You should ha' been round with her.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: I was round with her ▪ I called her ass and coxcomb,
And twenty more names, unless I should
Have called her whore, I could not be more round with her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I do not mean that way.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: And she called me,
I thank her.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Why no worse than her sins, heaven forgive her,
she has the more to answer; nay she did
Not stick to bid me die too, in that desperate
Estate.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Come, you shall take another course.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What ails my masters sweet-heart, she frighted?
I met and asked her for my master, and
She turned tail like a hound had lost the scent;
There's something in the wind, my three piled worship
Are you there with my lady o'th' larder,
Now in that posture? do not they two look like
A fine brick house and a thatched barn in the country,
Laying their heads together? they ha' spied me.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come hither close, nay he's faithful, and one that
Has a desire to serve you; you may trust him ▪

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Your worship may trust me a-bed with — I
Have had a itch this great while, sir, a kind
Of longing to be one of your appurtenances:
I have some faults, and I'll confess 'em; I have
A humour now and then, when I am asked
A question, to tell true, though I be chid for't;
And I do not love blows; you may sooner beat
My brains out, than a word of flattery:
I cannot batten upon commendation,
Without my wages, nor be valiant
Upon small beer; I am not overmuch
Given to be drunk, but I've a trick o'th Dutchman,
To do your business as well drunk as sober:
I have not impudence enough to pimp
For you, but I have a gift I can say nothing:
I was born upon Shrove-tuesday, and shall be
Now and then given to rebellion:
My flesh will once a year rise at a chambermaid;
If none such take me down, I shall in malice
And deep revenge, fling out upon May-day,
Among the prentices, without fear or wit.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay he has a sense,
And shall be of our counsel: look you close,
There is a plot to help this gentleman;
At night when they're a-bed , and if you went
To bed betimes, to avoid suspicion,
'Twere ne'er the worse; I'll say you are not well:
D'ye mark? this honest, honest gentleman shall be
Let into mistress Francis bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You shall only attend,
To give him notice from me when to come,
And watch about the house, he may get off
Without discovery; this is all.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: So, so, I shall not keep the door.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Let me alone to give you notice who
Stirs about house. Enter Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Away, 'tis Mr. Hartwell;
We'll not be seen together.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Go your ways,
A foolish knave and bawd, that do want nothing
But carting; I would sooner see that triumph,
Than all the pageants, a day after Simon
And Jude, when the fine city goes a feasting.
O sir, I have news; yes, they are gone, brave news;
Your gentlewoman can hold out no longer;
This night there will be a stratagem:
Old madam Hump a pomp, the nurse, has promised
To admit the country gentleman, when all
Are a-bed , into her chamber; yes, your mistress:
I'm o'th' plot, to lie perdue, and give
The word, if any firelock approach
The rest; imagine if he have not art to
Persuade her to the feat with him, yet there
Be tricks, and he may be surprised in the chamber,
and she may be compelled to marry him in
Her own defence; there have been such devices.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Then thou wilt be so base?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: And I had meant it,
I ne'er had told you this: can you make use
Of this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I have it; canst
By any means procure me but his clothes?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: With ease, he'll go to bed betimes, to avoid
Suspicion; that's a part of our design.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I could not wish a happy opportunity,
To try how she affects this gaudy fool,
And clear my faith to her, which her mother's watch
Will not permit; she has, I fear, perceived
My new familiarity with her mother,
Which I am compelled too, and must clear this way:
Fail me not, close, and propound thy own
Reward.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Tell me your purpose, and let my wit
Dispose of him.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: And you fall to prayers
With good love, look about us, I shall suspect
You won't thrive; you should go to a wench,
As gentlemen to oysters, without ceremony
Or saying grace; devotion will spoil all.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Witty engineer;
But was she taken with the plot?

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I was compelled to frame the outside of a reason,
Lest our own mirth should play the traitor with us,
Her spleen was so dilated, he believed
I have made her mad, which change makes for us.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: And he that we employed, the pursuivant,
Showed such a fiery rascal, the poor usurer
Trembled, as bawds beneath the lash.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: With as much joy, as to receive a hanging:
He would be whipped, and say his prayers i'th' church
In a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: That were no penance to him.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: Nay, he would pay as much as he should fine
For alderman, though half his soul went with it,
For his quietness; he doth apprehend
Nothing but earthquakes.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: How am I rampant
With the imagination? bid the music
Be ready, they know all their flourishes;
But shift you quickly for your other part,
My honourable lords;
How they do look like statesman, where's your toothpick?
Excellent; bear your staff handsomely, contract
The brow, and look more superciliously.

sp.p: I warrant you for my part.

sp.l: We came now
From practice.
These very clothes have made me proud already,
It was some lords cast suit, I'll lay my life. Enter one with perfume.

sp.p: And mine, it smells of honour.
He looks pale: my lord, how d'ye?
Well, well, I hope 'tis but conceit it.

sp.l: Will the pox lie in clothes? I can not tell,
I find some alteration in my body ▪
Sin be I shifted.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: 'Tis a mere conceit,
They were an honest man's, upon my knowledge,
A captain of the train band in the country,
They were brought against the general master last ▪
He were 'em that day, and to church the Sunday
Following, and most carefully seen 'em up,
To taste our London lavender.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Be sprightly; where's this prince?
See and attend him in fit state.

div.stage: Enter cousin for the King, and lords, sir Clement ▪ flourish.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Now by that sprig, a pretty majesty;
But wilt thou not be out of thy King's part?
And when the wine is wanting at the banquet,
Call upon drawers, quarrel with your nobles,
Or when we shall present our man of mortgages,
Take him aside, and borrow half a crown,
To give your whore benevolence, which trifled
For you last tilting, or be 〈…〉
And leave our project in the dirt.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: My lords,
This fellow's insolence must be corrected;
Dispose him in what prison you think fit.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: To bedlam with him then,
Is this a place for fools or madmen, who
Admitted him? take him, see you
He be well whipped, and let him thank our mercy,
Bandog.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I quake already, excellent Warbucks,
Cool, cool thy lungs, and whisper with some lord,
Thou wilt be a key too high else, good sir Clement,
Master of the house, at whose cost we are entertained.

sp.speaker: Sir Cle.
sp.l: My part is rotten
In my head, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.p: He waits in the first chamber.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Let the lutes
Begin, and their best voice, and then admit him. Soft music.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Here's revelling, my purse must be squeezed for't:
That's the King, the rest are bare; how supple they are
I'th hams, that courtier has oiled his joints,
He looks this way, they point at me; a rot
O'that knave's finger.

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: It was his grace's pleasure, he was sent for,
My good lord.
Mr. Hornet?
Let me have the honour to present him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Is this the man whom all so much commend
For his ability.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: I smell no good from that word, ability.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Discreet and read i'th' commonwealth, a man
Fit for employment in the state.

sp.speaker: Sir Clem.
sp.l: If the King of Spain
Had but his head, that politic head,
I know who might go fish for the Low-countreyes.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: They praise me, I am a thousand pound the worse for't.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: What must I pay for it?
I'll sell it any friend of yours again,
For half the money.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Some have care to give
His body more becoming ornaments;
He shall be like himself, and then we will confer
More honours on him. Exit pursuivant.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: Do you make haste, his grace
Will have you new thatched; you must have clothes
Fitting your state and honourable title.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: These will be good enough for me, alas I am not able.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo ▪
sp.l: Nay, you must have 'em from his wardrobe, sir,
They'll cost you nothing; you'll not look in those,
Like a poor knight of Windsor.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: When he is ready, give us knowledge.

sp.l: You were best prepare,
Your clothes will be here presently, the King
Will send for you before you be ready; cast
Your old skin off: do you not to 〈◊〉 sheets
And trouble, wrap yourselves a night i'th blankets?
Or are they ashamed to show the linings?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Hum? if this be but preparative to a whipping,
What case am I in? Enter servants with clothes.
Well said, now they are come;
Be nimble now, and help to fit sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Alas, must I wear this doublet? it would yield
Heaven knows how much to burn.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: You may be disparate
When 'tis on, and burn your body with it, sir,

sp.speaker: 1 lor.
sp.p: Be that time we ha' done wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Fit as they were made, sir.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: I am the man you please to call sir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Then I congratulate your happy fortune;
You're like to be exalted, his grace talks
Much on you, I'll be proud to be your servant:
My lord, a word.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The bridegroom, sir, in great favour, I can tell you,
And new created by his highness, baron
Of landscape; his living is far off.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: My very good lord, my breeches are almost on.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: His grace has pleased to shine upon
A piece of barren earth.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You are too modest;
The King has been informed, sir Gyles, you are
One of the ablest men in his dominion:
Should virtue still be clothed in rags? Advance it
To honour, and regard you waste your brain
At home, in cheap and low engagements, sweat
Your soul out, for a poor and paltry living;
Old houses, let 'em fall to the dull lord
O'th' manner; switch me up a town together,
Or meddle not; this or that sttragling acre's
Not worth your care; study some monopoly,
May sweep the kingdom at a stake; despise
A project won't bring in half the city;
Find out a way to forfeit all the charters;
Have an exchequer of your own, and keep
The princes round about in pension:
These are becoming businesses, and speak
An active state-man.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You do talk strange things,
My lord.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: His keys are things very
Material to our business.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: So, so:
I will account it one of my felicities,
To be a witness of your honour, sir.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: O, my good lord of landscape.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: The hangman will not have them, and I fear,
They will corrupt a well; i'faith give them stable room.

sp.speaker: 3 lo.
sp.l: My lord, the King asks for you; good sir Gyles
Write me i'th' number of your faithful friends.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: Do not yet say he's ready,
The barber has a duty to dispatch,
He will be hours a rubbing, washing, powdering.
Then I'll attend him to his presence.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: We shall excuse him so long, still your servant.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.p: The barber, sir, attends in the next room.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: Talk not you of charge,
You have but yet your welcome: do not you
Think, good sir Gyles, but we can shave you too. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Close, Startup in his shirt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I told him, sir,
You lay in a chamber o'th tother side,
the house, whither he is gone with his sword drawn,
And curses of themselves able to kill you:
You did affront him once, and now his mistress
Has quite neglected him, for your love, he thinks:
He'll make you an example to all rivals;
I'll bring your clothes hereafter, yet your fear
And running, sir, will keep you warm enough.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Honest close, thou hast saved my life.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Death, is he not behind you? this way, good sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Ha' you not made a fine choice, I did ever
Think he was false; your mother did but counterfeit
The lovesick widow all this while, to try him.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She told me so herself,
Assuring him the state was hers, and you
At her devotion; put him to his choice,
To take her with the wealth, or you with nothing:
What followed, you have heard, come be wise yet,
And love the country gentleman that dotes on you;
He's rich, and half a fool, I'll fetch him to you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My mother counterfeit? why may not Hartwell
Pretend as well as she, fearing her anger
And policy, if he refused her love?
I have observed some sorrow in his gestures,
As he were willing to deliver something,
If opportunity would give him leave ▪
He cannot be so false, now I suspect
He does obey some dire necessity:
'Twould puzzle a wise lover to be so
Severely put to't.

div.stage: Nurse brings in Hartwell in startups clothes ▪

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: On like a bold captain,
Give her a broad side, she's within your shot,
I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Nay, fly not before you hear.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: If my voice
Betray me not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why in this shape? some trick in't,
He hides his face, I'll put him to't however,
Although the hour be unseasonable, any time
We may express our joy: my nurse once told me
You were not well, and gone to bed, your health
Is welcome as my own; I dare not, sir,
In modesty presume to bid you stay,
And to requite your pains, kind Mr. Startup.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Forgive me if I blush,
I have no other way, but to declare
My eyes that late frowned on your love shall smile.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: On none but you: I have been too
Unkindly dealt withal by Hartwell, whom
How dear I affected, good heaven knows:
But I have read discretion to my fancy,
And were he here, he should be witness of
My vows to you, if you accept my heart,
And can with equal truth embrace it, I
Will choose my husband here; you, only you,
This faith be registered in heaven, shall challenge from me a wife's obedience.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Away, your mother's up; I would not for
A thousand pound she find you in this chamber.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have undone myself. Exit Frances.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Startup, to your own lodging,
Take that close lantern with you:
Passion of me, what makes her rise?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Discover; what?
Ha, Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: O, we are wretched, miserable, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: O, who shall lead me to a world where are
No women? Farewell all, I'll be above
Your charms, and find out death, a cure for love. Exit.

div.head: Act. iv.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Where are we now? 'tis very cold, why dost not
Lead me to some house?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: What, at this time a night?
All people are a-bed , the very owls
Are in their dead sleep; or if we could
Be admitted, would you venture a this fashion,
And publish your disgrace, proclaim yourself
Coward, and lay some imputation
Upon the place you came from, where your hopes
May yet be fair for marriage? This brunt over.
To meet some drunkard now were comfortable,
Whose eyes inflamed might serve for torches,
Or he might spit flapdragons from his fire
Of sack, and light us: but no sober man,
Considering what case you are in, sir,
By my consent should see you.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Now 'tis gone: 'tis bright
Again, is't not a spirit? O deliver me.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: I have heard some such things use to walk the fields.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Pray, pray with as much strength
As if you had no land, or were confined
To my annuity: now I fear no spirits;
This riches makes us cowards; hide yourself,
I will go nearer.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Dost know the devil if thou seest him, close?
A pox of love, if this be the reward on't;
Some call it fire, but I find no such matter;
I am frozen to the blanket, and my teeth
Strike one another, and keep time like hammers
That beat a psalm upon the virtuous anvil;
I do believe if they were beaten out,
They would make false dice, there's quicksilver in 'em,
I know already by their dancing.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: 'Tis my master with a dark
Lantern, that pursues us: by
This darkness, 'tis his voice, wrap yourself up,
And roll into some ditch, flight will betray us.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: I had as good be killed, but yet I'll venture. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, and more than I expected:
The matters do not fadge well with his mistress.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: What a sweet thing is night? how calm and harmless?
No whispering, but of leaves, on which the breath
Of heaven plays music to the birds that slumber;
Here are no objects to betray our sense
To repentance, nor can women, thus
Advantaged by the tapers of the night,
Spread their temptations to undo poor man:
What a fine book is heaven? which we may read
Best now, when every star is a fair letter:
How much they wrong thee night, which call thee guilty
of rapes and murders: 'tis the day, that like
A glorious whore, engages men to act 'em,
And taking then the darkness to obscure 'em:
We unjustly lay the shame upon thy brows,
That art so innocent; thou never sawest them
Befriended with this silence; I begin
To wander: there's no wilderness abroad,
To him that's lost at home.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: One that has taken pains for you tonight :
I am close.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I wait upon
My charge; I led your rival a procession
In's shirt, persuading him you had resolved
To cut his throat else; he's hard by at's prayers,
And thinks you ha' pursued him.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Ha, I'll do't;
Show me the fool, by all my hopes I'll kill him,
And send his base heart as a present to her:
Fate has preserved me with this revenge,
And I will not delay his death a minute.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: Why then
There is no fear but he'll live long enough;
I'll undertake he ne'er shall go provided
To fight w'ee; and for other satisfaction,
Name it, and take it; so I'll fetch him to ye.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Stay, I have been too passionate, let him live
To be her punishment; that's revenge enough,
While I pursue my own ways.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Whither thou must not follow, by thy honesty,
I charge thee come not after me.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: But not when I command
The contrary, if thou dost move this way,
Thou drawest my anger; mind the preservation
Of the tame thing you undertook; farewell,
If thou dost love me, follow not, nor question
'Tis in my power to lose thee or myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I cannot see i'th' darke with spectacles,
And mine own eyes ha' lost him o'the sudden;
Well, I must hope the best; what shall I do
With my hen-hearted lover, that would give
Half his estate his cold fit were well over:
I shall make work for the physicians:
Candles and cullises will ne'er restore him;
If he but scape with life, I am not sorry,
He may be a soldier, and endure the trenches;
I put him first to the becoming sufferance:
But what are these? an army of horns and halberds?
Upon my conscience, the watch; I thought
The fields had not been haunted with these goblins:
I cannot run; if I should squat, and they find me ▪
There were no mercy but Bridewell,
Or some such lovely place; I am resolved
To cast away a few good words upon 'em,
A leg and worshipping; the constable
That leads the rusty regiment will quit me,
I pass the gates wo't often, and so may
The devil if he pay the porter; bless you:
My masters what o'clock is't?

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.p: At Islington, and please you, about business.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Some thief, I warrant him, no honest man,
I know by his basket hilt, some rogue that watches,
The fields are pestered with such sturdy robbers.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He is a rogue that watches, for my part.
How Mr. constable? you are one yourself.
We will provide you a lodging.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But are you in earnest, gentlemen?
If there be no remedy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I have a companion hereabouts: where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: They seldom go alone:
We'll find him out; ha sirrah.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: I thank you honest men: where art thou close?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Here; these good men will help us to a lodging.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Blessing on their hearts, I am almost starved.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Yes, we'll do you that favour; come away, sir.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: I follow, sir, I cannot leave you in adversity;
All this is for your health, clean straw is warm, sir;
You have the benefit of being naked:
I shall have work tomorrow in the woollen.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Away, away; bring them away. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I heard some noise; look, call up the servants,
See if the gentlemen be a-bed ; I'm troubled.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Mr. Startup is not a-bed , and here is all is left
Of Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I dare not tell her of his shift, they're gone,
The doors I found left open, and no sign
Which way they are bestowed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: This puzzles me:
Pray heaven there be no mischief in this absence:
Is Frank a-bed?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What should move 'em
To leave my house so late, and Mr. Hartwell
Without his clothes? Some knock there:
Beshrew me but I trembled.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: 'Tis a stranger,
And says he would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: At this late hour?
What accidents are these? from whence?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Has he no name? what should this mean?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: He says he is a countryman of Mr. Startups.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Admit him, he perhaps does bring some news.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By your leave mistress, pardon my importunity
At so unfit an hour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I met with fortunate directions,
Though I came late; I understand you have
A guest, one Startup of Northamptonshire,
That comes a-wooing to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Such an one there was that supped with us, and went
To bed; but since, as I have faith, I know not
Which way he has conveyed himself; another
Gentleman too is missing, and his rival.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Pray do not mock me, lady, I ha' rid
a great way, and the business much concerns him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You may believe me, he is no such treasure
I should conceal him. Enter Frances.

sp.speaker: Countryman
sp.l: Then I see you dally:
Know, mistress, you may slack your preparations,
Your daughter must look out another husband,
He is contracted.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: And something more,
Gotten with child one, that without blushing
I cannot call my daughter; he shall make
Her credit straight again, although my fortunes
Have no equality with his, I shall
Find law to force him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You preferred this suitor,
This news returns my blood.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Sir, you shall find
All truth I have delivered, I am not sorry,
To hear this news, this is no time to seek him:
Please you accept the lodging that was his,
My servant shall attend you in the morning,
To help your search.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: You seem a noble gentlewoman,
I take your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nurse, a light; pray walk, sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I was unkind to Hartwell, he not wise;
But love still apprehends too much, or nothing. Exit countryman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Frances, a word: do not you know what is
Become of these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not I, their absence
Is strange to me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: This gentleman, Mr. Hartwell,
Whom we shall never see again, I fear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How, mother? are you acquainted
with any cause to fear thus.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis in vain
To tell thee how I loved him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Bless my senses! you love him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Above all the world, affectionately placed him
Too near my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I heard you made pretence
Of love, to try him for my sake; and pardon me,
If yet I dare not believe more.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My heart doth thrill, I feel a coldness run
Through all my veins already.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I had no other thought,
At first; but wisely to distinguish whether
His heart was fixed on thee, or my estate;
With resolution, if I found him more
A courtier of thy fortune than thy person,
To punish him with loss of both: but love
Hath changed both scene and title in our comedy,
And what I meant should shipwreck all his hopes,
Hath ruined us, his modest and calm answer:
To accept my tender, with such force and reason
Directed to my fancy, turned my purpose,
And made me his indeed, his perfect lover:
But now we ha' both lost him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All the piety
That ever taught children to love their mother,
Will but suffice to keep my heart obedient.
Was ever maid so miserable? Was there
No other, in my fate, to rival me
I live too long; o break, break my poor heart;
For she that gave me life, hath taken it from me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do not weep, or if
I do, I know not why.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Now I perceive
thy duty was but counterfeit, you love him,
Upon my life you love him still; have my
Commands no more respect? My care and love
So ill rewarded, that my heart desiring
One comfort in the world, and shall my child
Rise up to take it from me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas I knew not
You loved him too, indeed I had rather die
Than you should call me rebel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Now I see
The cause of his departure in this fashion,
Pray heaven he have not made away himself:
Did ever child deceive a mother so?
I have a sad presage, you may to bed,
And rise without my blessing, yet
You may stay, wherefore should I despair
Of his return? You say you could not tell
That I affected him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Indeed not I,
And do believe it now against my will;
But I am your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Show it, in confirming
Yourself to my desires, and what is past,
I can forgive you, if he come again:
Will you be ruled, and show no favour to him?
For 'tis in you, I see, to make me happy;
I will not tie you to affect the other,
Choose any for your husband but this man,
My love and prayers shall go along with you;
Answer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Indeed I dare not, yet could I
Put off the knowledge that you are a mother —

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Though in imagination I allow you
The greatest woman in the earth, whose frown
Could kill, and eyes at pleasure make alive
again; I could say —

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I durst tell you,
In confidence of my cause, that you betray
Two innocents to sorrow; and though heaven
Look on, and seem to smile upon your cruelty,
Yet there is punishment for divorcing those
Whose hearts that hath conjoined: I durst tell you,
Though all your terrors were prepared to punish
My bold defence; you were a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A most unjust, a sacrilegious tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You would not be so violent.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That thus,
Not only ruin and deface the altar,
But steal away the very sacrifice ▪
And I durst add and smile upon your anger.
Though as you frowned death stood in every wrinkle,
My soul's above your tyranny, and would
From torturing flame, receive new fire of love,
And make your eye faint to behold the brightness
Of my poor body's martyrdom; and if ever
Love showed a miracle, my heart should bear
The characters of him you have torn from it,
With beams about it like a saint that suffered:
But as you are my mother, thus I kneel
And beg a pardon for my innocence,
If that offend you; live you happy still,
And be the mistress of your vows, live to
Enjoy whom you affect, may every hour
Return new blessings on you both; renew
Your spring, and let him think you young again,
And let me beg but this for all my duty;
Against that day you marry him to provide
My coffin, for I fear I shall, not have
〈…〉 after, to pray for you.
The herbs that shall adorn your bridal chamber,
Will serve my funeral, and deck my hearse;
Beneath which you should say, there lies your daughter
That dies to show obedience.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why shouldst thou
Continue thus to him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I know he loves me, yet hereafter your affections
May not.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But never procure thee one sad thought;
Now I have tried you both; assure my child,
I loved him but for thee, dispose thyself
To be his bride: this news, at his return,
Will make all well to rest.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Twere sin to mock thee any more: to bed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'll spend all night
In prayers for you, mother: o my HartwellExeunt.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: I am bound ever to thee.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: Does she not become her rich clothes too?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: The morning never looked
So fresh, nor Venus with more charms upon her:
Adon would melt before her eye, and woo her
Her kisses, at expense of his last breath:
Cupid himself, could he but see, would fall
In love with her, and throwing away his shafts,
Offer the empty quiver to her eyes,
Ambitious to fill it with her beams;
The least of which, would wound more hearts, than ail
His stock of golden arrows.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Didst thou not know before, that love is able,
Without the help of sack, to make a poet,
My nimble Mercury, Jove's herald in
Reversion?

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I must confess
I had a trick of Mercury when I picked
His pocket for the keys.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: His eyes were drenched in suds, and I returned 'em
Ere they recovered light.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent;
He walks in darkness still.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: His clothes already have
Made him forget himself, or if he have
But the remembrance of such a woman;
The more he sees her now, the more he'll think
The change impossible.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I'th' gallery, where with much patience,
He does expect his highness will send for him.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: Then all runs smooth, his wonder still continues.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I fed that humour artificially;
He is half persuaded all's but a dream,
To which imagination his clothes
Are a great help, because he paid not for 'em:
Sometimes he is very merry, then again
He struts about with such a scurvy pride,
As some new crept into nobility;
When men of their first livery come to see 'em;
His honour has so change him, that he now
Knows not of what religion he is;
Or if he chance to think of his first faith,
He spits o'th hangings, and excused with,
I do not like the story, 'tis apocryphal:
Sometimes he'll offer at a jest, and talk
Nonsense with him that has been seven years lorded;
Frown upon any man that will presume
To have more knowledge, in worse clothes; I told him
It was his grace's pleasure he should be
Controller of the masque, and he did sweat,
as he were studying for some mighty oaths
To clear the presence: he is here; away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: And you are master of the house, sir Clement,
For so I heard you called.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.l: It is my name,
Sir Gyles, unworthy of this grace his highness
Is deigned to show in honouring of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: And was she married this morning, say you?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: This morn she lost her virgin name.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I have not seen her yet, nor any of the ladies,
You have but little noise methinks in the house.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Who, as you say, came hither privately, with a small train
Of lords; would I might see his face again;
I am not sent for yet, I have been ready,
Sir Clement, these three hours, and I do wonder
His grace forgets himself so much.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: That music speaks him on entrance.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: Ay, that garb becomes him;
How was his person lost within that shape
He was first presented to me?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Indeed the case is somewhat a
Altered, by your highness' bounty
To your poor subject, Hornet.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Now he looks
As he did scorn the quorum, and were hungry
To eat a statesman; alas an office in
The household is too little for a breakfast:
A baron, but a morning's draught, he'll gulp it,
Like a round egg in muscadine: methinks
At every wiping of his mouth, should drop
A golden saying of Pythagoras;
A piece of Machiavell; I see already
Hang on his beard (Which wants but stroking out)
the statutes and the magna charta have
Taken a lease at his tongue's end.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I will think on't;
He shall be — but toth' banquet,
Then let the mask be ready, there we shall
Employ your worthy diligence.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Heaven bless your mighty grace.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: You'll follow.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I attend you presently:
I know not what to think of these things yet,
'Tis very strange I should be thus exalted
Without desert; best known unto myself.
Princes I see are mortal, and may be
Deceived in placing of their honours, I
Am little better than a favourite,
If this be true: if? 'tis a question,
Let me consider wisely, it may be
I am not I. No, no, I am a knight:
Are these my clothes? I did not use to wear such
A pocket in my sleeve and velvet hose,
Six times translated since they were a midwife's
Forepart, were things I wore on holidays.
The price of these would break a camel's back,
And yet some men walk under 'em like elephants,
And have variety, as the devil were
Their tailor, who best knows where all their land lies.
Then why this cost on me? it is a dream,
And I am very glad on't, 'tis impossible
I should be true, it does not hang together,
I will have patience till i wake again,
And care not what becomes on't.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.l: 'Tis his highness'
Pleasure now the banquet's done.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: How, the banquet done? I was coming to't,
You could hardly say grace by this time.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.l: That's a ceremony grown out of use;
It was a running banquet.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: A running? so it seems, it made great haste:
I do dream certainly, there's no sense nor reason
In any thing they say.

sp.speaker: Sir Clem.
sp.l: You know your place,
The mask will straight begin, and his grace won't
Have any one admitted, he resolves,
If the conceit affect him, it shall be
Performed i'th' court hereafter, i'th' mean time
He does command all privacy: there are
Some set to guard the door; but your care must
Provide his highness be not interrupted.
Back, they are rude already.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Let me alone:
What turbulent knave is that?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I am a country gentlemen, sir Gyles;
And if I may presume upon good clothes,
You may before his grace call me your cousin,
And not be ashamed; here is a lady too.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: A lady too? Is she with child? What makes she
Here, and she be with child already?
'Tell thee none such shall be admitted, while
I am in place: more rapping? Keep the doors,
If I do fall a swearing once, look to't.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I beseech you, for my wife's sake.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Thy wives?
What's he that pleads in forma pauperis?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A citizen, and like you.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Like me? thou liest: I am more like a lord.
Thou shalt fare never the better for that word:
Knock down the women, and there be a hundred.
And make their husbands drunk; the guard are lazy:
These women's insolence will force a statute,
I will petition to the King myself,
They may have liberty but once a year
to see the galley foist, then be confined
To their chamber, and one prentice — yet again.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Sir Gyles, sir Gyles, you know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: But while I am in office I'll know nobody .

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Draw thy purse, wherein
Thou keepest thy ears, and leave 'em at the door;
The guard trust none without a pawn; they'll serve,
If they be never redeemed, to seethe in milk
For a sore throat: Jews ears I know they are.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: My niece? the devil she is.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Her very voice: ha? open the doors there;
Where is she?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: My niece that called to me.

sp.speaker: With.
sp.p: None called: nor was there any woman here.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: No, nor my scrivener bawling out, sir Gyles,
Not at any hand your worship.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Then I dream,
And I am a fool to make a question on't.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: The knaves laugh at me, but let 'em, I
Shall be as merry with this tale tomorrow:
What fancies men have in their sleep sometimes?
His highness.
Where be the ladies?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis no matter, why do I ask the question?

sp.speaker: 1 la.
sp.l: Wilt please your grace? Gives papers to the King and sir Gyles.
And you sir Gyles, the subject of the masque.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: What's here, the three goddesses
Contention for the golden ball?
sp.stage: Enter Playfaire, dancing, with a golden ball in his hand.
sp.l: This is Paris; so.
These are the three goddesses;
Juno, Pallas, Venus.

div.stage: The goddesses dance, and court Paris for his ball: to Juno enters one like a King; takes his crown and sceptre, offers it to Paris, he refuses.

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.p: Juno doth woo him with her state and kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: But he refuses, more fool he.

div.stage: To Pallas, enter one like a soldier armed, with a book in his hand; she presents them to Paris, he neglects.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.l: He is not for her service, though she offer
To make him scholar and a soldier:
A complete man.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: No, no, that fairy must win the ball.
sp.stage: To Venus comes Cupid, leading in Hornet's niece, richly dressed.
sp.l: Ha? that's my niece.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: That whom dame Venus and her dandiprat
Are busy withal.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Married this morning; 'tis my daughter, sir.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Nay, if she be my niece, I am sure she was not
Married this morning.
sp.stage: Paris receives the niece, and gives Venus the ball; Juno, Pallas, with their masquers, exeunt.
sp.l: She's safe enough at home,
And has but half her wits, as I remember:
The devil cannot juggle her from my custody.
Ha, ha, I do dream still.

div.stage: Cupid joins their bands, and sings; which done, exeunt masquers.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: 'Tis time to break off revels: how like you this, sir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I see you'd be a-bed ; you are not used
To these late hours.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I humbly beg your licence
I may return to my own lodging.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.p: Lights for sir Gyles: one shall attend you home.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: At a conceit, at a conceit:
What did I eat last night, to make me dream thus?

div.head: Act. v.
div.stage: Enter Hartwell apprehended, countryman officers, servant.

sp.speaker: Countryman
sp.l: Would you had done no worse.
These are his clothes, and you must give account
How you came by 'em, and produce him safe
Ere you acquit yourself; we may suspect
You ha' killed him.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Then I obey my destiny;
Justice I see pursues the guilty person:
Dispose me where you please.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Whate'er you be, you can but have my life
For his; all your revenge can reach no higher:
And to the law I yield myself.

sp.speaker: Countryman
sp.l: My hopes are cold
As his blood whom thou hast slain: thou hast
Been cruel in this act, to me and mine;
Whose fames in him are miserably wounded:
But look for the reward.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I must expect it;
In the mean time I do not beg your mercy:
Life is a burden, I would fain be rid on't.
Does he weary me to carry it?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do so: to the next justice; come away

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: She's gone, she's gone, I shall run mad; my niece,
Robbed of three thousand pound in her escape,
I find too late, I am awake and gulled,
nor know I whom to accuse for my tormentors;
Devils or men, but sure they were not men,
But very fiends I revelled with last night.
That I could meet the prince of devils that knighted me,
The poets call him Pluto, god of riches;
I and my learned council would undo him
In law, in very law, which he should find
Hotter ere I had done, than hell itself,
And call his place of torment, in three terms,
But a refreshing to't: yet let me see,
I have the portion still, though she be vanished,
That's better than my niece, but if she marry,
I lose it all there; there's the vexation.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: 'Tis too late, away,
I do not love unnecessary compliment.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Yes, I am he; am I not very fine?
What do you think this trim will cost me, ha?
Three thousand pounds, no more?

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: The broker won't
Lend half the money.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Will you, sir, be gone,
I ha' no money to lend now, it is not,
You know, in fashion, with rich clothes.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I came for other purpose, and with news perhaps,
