You would be willing to receive; you have
A niece?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: No; such a creature was in my possession:
Do you know where she is?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Ha, good sir? pray forwards:
You shall have money upon good security.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I thank you, sir, for nothing; I do owe you
Too much already, on these terms.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: My niece, as you were saying.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: No general rumour; by a chance I came
Where such a thing was whispered only whispered;
Just as he was described: in my opinion
You're very handsome, and do look as like a reverend —

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: Why, you shall have it, sir.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: But touching my niece, good sir,
That most ungracious giglet,
That's run or stolen away, juggled last night
Out a my doors.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: Did not she leap the casement?

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Do not increase my agony; you came —

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: With civil meaning to discover how
You may be abused.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: What money do you want, sir?
Your own bond shall suffice.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I ha' sworn never
To write my name or mark; but I can tell —

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Where I may find this girl.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: More I can do, if need require;
'Tis in my power to give
Her back to your possession, and I am willing.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: On reasonable conditions, and such
As shall not trench on borrowing money.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: For you shall give it freely and get by't;
For you must understand if I do this,
I shall betray a friend of mine, that has
Put me in trust, one that intends to marry her,
(For truth to tell, they are not yet contracted)
To marry her, d'ye mark? and yet ere morning
Three thousand pounds upon her, is't not so much?
One that has lent me sums too without parchment.
Or foolish circumstance, to be repaid;
Which you were never yet so much a christian,
As to be guilt of, in your usurer's gallon
Of conscience melting sack; this deserves something,
But cause some expedition is required;
You have a bond of mine.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I had but forty, and your scrivener paid,
With whom, perhaps, your worship too divided;
If you remember, there were precious dinners,
Ere I could count my chickens altogether,
Which was your thrift and my expense; you shall
First cancel that bond, nay this won't dot,
And give, d'ye mark, give me a hundred pieces,
Perhaps I'll drink your health: this shall retrieve
Your niece, and give her into your hands,
Though for my treachery, I be sung in ballads,
And have the town curse if ever I marry.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: 'Tis too much for no more labour, sir.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: If I consider,
Three hundred will not bring me to't again;
Thus fair I'll deal with you; I'll not touch your money
Till I ha' don't, but then I will be sure:
Fetch, fetch the business.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I will have ready money too: you have
Bags of all sizes and denominations.
Ay, these things promise well; now I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Do this fear for me, and 'tis all thine own.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Now we may wish you say, the priest has tied
That knot no subtlety nor malice can
Dissolve; and repent not I have been
An actor in your comedy, though I should not
be tempted easily to such another
Engagement; for your sake I have dispensed with
My person and my place.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You always were
My loving uncle.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Sir, you have, in this,
Deserved our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: It was good mirth
To hear him confident all our device
Was but a dream.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: He is awake by this time;
Should your cousin fail, we'll have another way
To invite him; and if honesty prevail not,
Force him till he consent.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Some offenders are brought to be examined.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Nephew, withdraw, and you, fair bride; these troubles
Are incident to my place, I'll soon dispatch 'em.
How now my masters? Mr. Hartwell? ha!

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Look on me; sir, as a delinquent; these
Are able to accuse me.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Nothing, but for killing of a man.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Mistress Bellamy,
You are come in a sad time: here's Mr. Hartwell
Accused for killing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis not possible.
Good sir believe it not.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: I am not worth your prey, gentle lady
In vain I should extenuate my fact,
to have the troubles of examinations;
Here I confess again, my hand is guilty
Of killing him whose feeble arm durst not
Lift up a weapon to defend himself.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I but slew a coward
Startup, and could I call his life again,
As soon I should destroy it; you perhaps
Know not my provocation: he has
My rival, sir, pardon me: mistress Bellamy,
To whom I only seemed a proselyte
In love, I had no heart to give from her:
And in my study to decline your anger;
I fell upon her scorn, which in few minutes,
Engaged me to this fate; not am I troubled
That I must die, when she upon whose faith
I durst have laid the hopes of my eternity,
Hath violated all the trust of woman.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Will't please you, sir —

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Tell me, most unkind, if thou didst love
At all? How couldst thou think I should be such
A desperate atheist, that thou so soon,
And with a strange apostasy shouldst revenge it?
These swelling drops which in thy innocence
Might ha' prevailed to ha' restored the dead,
Heaven now doth look on, and despise: and though
Thou shed moist tribute on this tomb, 't shall slide,
Neglected o'er the marble, and be lost,
As if the stone had sense to punish thy
Disdain of me: I can behold that weeping,
And not be moved to wish I were not guilty
Of killing him whose love had been thy triumph;
And I dare boldly, still in the contempt
Of what I am to suffer, and the justice
Of my own truth, challenge thy soul to answer
in what I was beneath that gaudy fool,
Excepting that he had more earth than I
To help his scale, which yet he may be indebt for
To his father's sins: alive, he could not merit
One cold disdain from thee; and dead, how comes it
He should be worth thy tears? But let thy eyes
Chide this unruly sorrow; dress thy cheeks
With their fresh blood again, and let thy face
Open a book of smiles, in the assurance
I have not long to live; when I have numbered
A few sad minutes, thou shalt be revenged,
And I shall never trouble thee: if this
Be not enough, extend thy malice further:
And if thou findest one man that loved me living,
Will honour this cold body with a grave,
Be cruel, and corrupt his charity.
So fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yet you must stay and hear me:
He sha'not suffer, if my friends or state
Can purchase him a pardon: where's the body
Of him that's slain?

sp.speaker: Countryman
sp.l: We know not; but you hear
His free confession of the fact.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: This may
Proceed from discontents; life to some man
Is but their torment in whose pain they will,
As on the wrack, confess what never
Was in their thought.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Speak it again, and I
Dare promise thee to live.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My heart was ever
Constant, my mother's love was but thy trial,
As mine a seeming change in thy disguise,
Which was not able to secure thee from 〈◊〉
The words were, I would choose my 〈…〉
But what will this avail us?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Mr. justice, I here discharge you.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: My joys obeys
No limits; I accused my false unjustly,
The fool's alive.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I know not that,
My servant's with him, but if he ha' played
The hangman, starved or smothered him in a ditch,
I ha' made fair work.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I had rather it had been my kinsman and the usurer;
But wait and give me knowledge when they come.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: It is he and close;
Then I am secure, your pardon, and thy love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You have it freely, and a mother's prayers
For both your happiness.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Please your worship, these
We took last night i'th' fields suspiciously,
And by my own authority I condemned 'em.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Shall we be hanged, close, we are condemned already.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: This is the gentleman was killed.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Sweet sir, no;
Not killed out right, but I was almost starved
With cold: these gentlewoman know me,
And I should know that hose and doublet too;
Those garments which you wear, I have oft seen, sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: I was fain to borrow
These of a prisoner that lies in, upon
My diamond ring.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Yes, and joy in every bosom.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: Close, you must know this your mistress: sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Clos.
sp.l: 'Tis enough for you to know her, sir,
And me to acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.p: Hum; yes, who brought you to town? And your daughter too, sweet sir?

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Is she grown crooked? I knew her too well.
Peace, not a word more, I know your meaning,
Do not discredit me, sweet sir, and we'll steal down
And marry her ere any be aware on't;
I won't stay to shift me, take no leave;
The jest will be when I am in the country,
How like an ass he'll look in my apparel. Exeunt Startup countryman,

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Playfair's cousin and the tother gallant.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: I must entreat your patience a little,
You'll meet with friends in the next room.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: Excuse my boldness, sir, this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: Mr. Hornet, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Good sir no ceremony; we are come
About business: I have lost my niece, and would
Know where she is.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.p: D'ye take me for a vizard?

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: Sir, our desires are modest; that you would
Be witness to a bargain, and receive
Some trifles, sir, in trust to be delivered
To me, if I restore his kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Not else; on that condition I deposit
These hundred pieces, and a bond, if he
Deliver me my niece, they are his fraught,
if not, they call me owner.

sp.speaker: C●us.
sp.l: Pardon, sir,
That I presume to bring this trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: You sha'not long expect: so rest you merry.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: As you see, fallen away an inch since morning,
But this will physic me; if I possess
This harlotry again, I'll make her sure:
Trust not a woman, they have found the herb
To open locks; not brazen towers can hold 'em.
Or if they get not lose, they have the virtue
Of loadstones; shut up in a box, they'll draw
Customers to them; nay, being dead and buried,
There is a suspicion they will break the grave,
Which puts so many husbands to the charge
Of heavy stones to keep their bad wires under.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: O Mr. justice you are honest,
I ha' been abused, so miserably cheated,
I am ashamed to think on't, stay, what, 〈…〉 ▪
Ha, 'tis my niece; the very same.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: There, sir, you have her, and I must ha' these.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Take 'em: but you shall go with me; have I found you?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: How uncle? A reveller? you'll lead meam coranto.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: What make you so familiar with my wife?

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: 'Tis upon record,
I'll bring a parson that shall take his oath on't

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Give me my hand and money, Mr. justice.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: Here, here, but not to be recovered
by law: I have a judgement, sir, against you.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You have conspired to rob, cheat, and undo me;
I'll have you all star-chambered.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Sir, be calm, and hear us.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Yes, you shall;
It will be necessary, I am bold,
Presuming on her favour, to demand
A parcel of three thousand pound, the sum
Belongs to me, by virtue of a marriage's
And I must have it.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.l: I saw the priest conjoin 'em:
He will deserve your love.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Perhaps you may continue
A thousand, or two thousand, for six months,
Upon security.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: Faith sir consider,
It is more safe to see her thus bestowed,
Than trust a jury; if the doctor had
Given her too much opium, or purged
Her soul away, things might so worse; but I
Keep counsel.

sp.speaker: Cousin
sp.p: For your own sake, and as you are true knight.

div.stage: Enter mistress Bellamy, Hartwell, Frances, and Close.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Now, ha ye done? The widow;
Not a word more, take her, I'll pay you sir,
Three thousand pounds tomorrow: noble widow
You were in the first list to be invited;
My niece I told you of, is married to
This worthy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to make it good; what say you,
Shall we have issue? Now the word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: You are resolved why, so: come hither nephew,
Shalt be my heir, I love thee for thy wit;
But charm thy friends, they do not laugh at me:
I'll be a knight too, if I live, and build
An hospital for twenty more o'th' order,
Which I'll reduce myself out of the suburbs;
It is a shame such men should lose their spurs
In women's petticoats, and turn squires again
To whores, or parasites to noble men,
For want of fit provision.

sp.speaker: Justice
sp.l: An excellent foundation.
But where's Startup?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Ne'er conjure for him; we are ingrateful to
Our bliss: but wasting of these precious minutes,
Which are so many ages, till the church
Hath made us perfect.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.l: Is there any more
Work for the priest? Then give you joy before hand,
And let us celebrate the day together.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I'm glad of your conversion; ye are the first
Jew that in my remembrance has turned christian.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Betwixt love and fortune, now the accounts are even:
A chain of hearts, and the first link in heaven.
